awd_titl_txt: The Correlation between Tornado Formation, Intensification, and Decay and Ground Features using Rapid-Scan Mobile Radar Observations, Damage Surveys, and GIS
awd_abstract_narration:
It has long been theorized that land surface and elevation changes play a role in tornado formation and intensity changes.  However, most studies have either been idealized modeling efforts or case studies on a particular event.  This award will provide funding to develop a climatology of tornado interactions with the surface with a goal of answering several pressing questions about how tornadoes are impacted by surface characteristics.  The main societal impact of the project is the potential for improving tornado warning accuracy, which is a significant public safety issue.  The project also involves outreach and training activities to improve public understanding of science and develop the next generation of researchers.

This overarching goal of the study is to determine if statistical relationships can be retrieved that correlate tornado formation/decay and intensity to non-atmospheric surface features such as land cover and topography.  The researcher plans to combine a large database of radar and damage survey data with GIS-based digital elevation maps and national land cover data sets to answer the following questions:  1) What is the statistical relationship between topographic characteristics or changes in topography and tornado intensity? 2) What is the statistical relationship between land cover characteristics changes in land cover and changes in tornado intensity? 3) Are relationships in (1) and (2) sensitive to a tornado's intensity? 4) What is the spatial relationship between tornadogenesis/decay locations and land cover type or topography?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to investigate relationships between tornado structure and behavior with physical characteristic of the underlying ground; namely land cover type (e.g., fields versus forests vs cities) and terrain elevation. The data used included rapid-scan, mobile radar data from the University of Oklahoma’s Rapid-Scan, X-band, polarimetric radar, digital elevation model datasets and land cover type datasets from the United States Geological Survey. Fundamentally, the questions investigated included: 1) How does terrain modify tornado intensity and structure, and 2) How does land cover modify tornado intensity and structure. Additional sub-questions included investigating if land cover type and terrain characteristics in a large-scale perspective (i.e., specific mountains/plateus/river valleys, etc.) and small-scale (localized pockets of trees vs fields, or small hills) may contribute to increased likelihood of tornado formation or dissipation. In brief, it was determined that terrain and land cover both can play direct roles in modulating tornado intensity, path, and structure (in terms of the distribution of rotating and vertical winds around the tornado’s center), but the effects were not consistent from case to case. For example, in some scenarios, tornadoes intensified moving uphill while in other scenarios they weakened moving uphill. Furthermore, preliminary work was performed employing a highly sophisticated numerical model where simplified terrain and land cover characteristics were included to study their effects on tornados in a controlled environment, where the parent storm and larger scale atmospheric conditions were held constant.  This work is important because it has been unclear to date how such physical variations in the land surface can cause changes in tornado intensity and structure.

Throughout the duration of this project, this work was disseminated to the broader scientific community through publications, and particularly through conference presentations. 4 journal articles were produced, and 15 presentations delivered by the PI, with 6 additional presentations delivered by student research assistants. Additionally, funding for this project enabled the development of a free, publically available severe weather climatology website for the State of Ohio designed for a general audience. Coupled with the Ohio Severe Weather Dashboard, a research centered website was also developed that highlights the work from this grant in additional to other work performed by the PI.

This work further supported the training and development of next-generation scientists including 7 undergraduate students and 4 M. S. students, 7 of whom were members of underrepresented populations.

This work will be continued by systematically investigating changes in land cover type and terrain in a high-resolution numerical model framework to isolate the contributions of terrain and land cover to specific tornado parameters including minimum central pressure, vertical velocities, and horizontal wind field characteristics (rotation, divergence, wind speed).  

 


Last Modified: 07/05/2024
Modified by: Jana B Houser

Images (1 of )
  • Distributions of path direction changes as tornadoes move uphill (blue) vs downhill (red). The clear delineation between the two distributions indicates that tornadoes turn left (negative bearing change) moving uphill and they turn right (positive bearing change) moving downhill
    Jana Houser, Wesley Collins
    Copyrighted
    Jana B Houser
    Relationship between Tornado Path and Terrain Change
  • Examples of the types of data available from the Ohio Severe Weather Dashboard website developed with funds from the award. County-based data of flooding, flash flooding, hail, thunderstorm winds, and tornadoes are all available.
    Jana Houser, Miranda Silcott, Ashlee Ziegler
    Copyrighted
    Jana B Houser
    Ohio Severe Climatology Example
  • This figure identifies locations where tornado formation is statistically higher than surroundings, and overlays terrain elevation and land cover type to arrive at spatial correlations between the two
    Jana Houser, Tyler Muncy
    Copyrighted
    Jana B Houser
    Hot Spot Analysis
